citeinfo.origin: U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) and the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS).
USDA Forest Service - Boise Aquatic Sciences Lab
citeinfo.title: NHDPlus Reconditioned Streams for Production Unit 17c

descript.abstract:
NHDPlus is an integration of the medium resolution (1:100,000) National Hydrography Dataset (NHD), the National Elevation Dataset (NED), and the Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD). NHDPlus includes improved networking, naming, and numerous attributes. NHDPlus also includes elevation-derived catchments (drainage areas). Refer to the NHDPlus User Guide for more information. http://www.horizon-systems.com/nhdplus/documentation.php
This reconditioned data set has been modified from the original NHDPlus data to ensure stream connectivity, which is required to fit spatial statistical models to stream network data. Braided channels, most canals, and disconnected streams were deleted from NHDPlus. Additionally, where three or more segments converged into a single downstream segment the stream layer was manually edited to offset two of the three segments. The FLoWS and STARS toolboxes were used to identify topological errors.
<http://www.fs.fed.us/rm/boise/AWAE/projects/SpatialStreamNetworks.shtml>
descript.purpose:
Spatial statistical models have been developed to model data along stream networks (Ver Hoef and Peterson 2010), however, it is extremely critical that the streams data are topologically correct to ensure that hydrologic distances and spatial relationships are calculated properly. Topological errors are common in GIS data and must be corrected, and streams must be digitized in the downstream direction, before the models are run. The FLoWS and STARS toolboxes were used to identify topological errors.
<http://www.fs.fed.us/rm/boise/AWAE/projects/SpatialStreamNetworks.shtml>
descript.supplinf:
For more information, refer to the NHDPlus Users Guide.
Other information about this project can be found at: http://www.fs.fed.us/rm/boise/AWAE/projects/SpatialStreamNetworks.shtml

theme.themekey: Spatially Referenced Regressions on Watershed Attributes
Spatial Statistical Modeling on Stream Networks
NorWeST regional stream temperature database and model

cntorgp.cntorg: USDA Forest Service - Boise Aquatic Sciences Lab

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.3000

citeinfo.origin: U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA)
citeinfo.title: National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) Medium Resolution

srctime.srccurr: The source NHD is a snapshot of the dataset accessed on 1/31/2004 and updated throughout 2004 and 2005.

srcinfo.srccontr: A snapshot of the NHD was used as the baseline framework from which enhancements to the network were built upon. Enhancements include feature names, network connectivity and network flow relationships. This enhanced NHD version was then used in conjunction with the NED, and WBD (where applicable) to create a HydroDEM, for generation of the catchment Grid/shapefile, and flow direction/accumulation Grids. The enhanced NHD was used to compute and assign flowline Value Added Attributes (VAAs) to this network.

citeinfo.origin: U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), EROS Data Center
citeinfo.title: National Elevation Dataset (NED)

srcinfo.srccontr: NED data used in combination with NHD, WBD (where applicable) to create a HydroDEM, to generate NHDPlus Catchments, surface flow direction and accumulation Grids. Stream elevations from NED which were used to help derive stream slope and stream velocity.
Source dataset used to assign catchment and flowline land cover attributes.

citeinfo.origin: Chris Daly and George Taylor of the Spatial Climate Analysis Service at Oregon State University.
citeinfo.title: United States Average Annual Precipitation, 1961-90

pubinfo.publish: Spatial Climate Analysis Service at Oregon State University (SCAS/OSU)

citeinfo.othercit: This dataset from the PRISM model, developed by Chris Daly of SCAS/OSU.

srctime.srccurr: Climatological period from which the point observations were taken.

srcinfo.srccontr: Source dataset used to compute mean annual precipitation for each catchment and area weighted precipitation for each flowline. Weighted precipitation values for each flowline was used as a variable in a Vogel equation for estimating mean annual streamflow. The Vogel estimates of mean annual flow were used as a source variable in a Jobson equation to compute mean annual stream velocity estimates.

citeinfo.origin: Chris Daly and George Taylor of the Spatial Climate Analysis Service at Oregon State University.
citeinfo.title: United States Annual Mean Temperature, 1961-90

pubinfo.publish: Spatial Climate Analysis Service at Oregon State University (SCAS/OSU)

citeinfo.othercit: This dataset from the PRISM model, developed by Chris Daly of SCAS/OSU.

srctime.srccurr: Climatological period from which the point observations were taken.

srcinfo.srccontr: Source dataset used to compute mean annual temperature for each catchment and area weighted mean annual temperature for each flowline. Weighted mean annual temperature values for each flowline was used as a variable in a Vogel equation for estimating mean annual streamflow. The Vogel estimates of mean annual flow were used as a source variable in a Jobson equation to compute mean annual stream velocity estimates.

citeinfo.origin: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service (NRCS) and the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS)
citeinfo.title: Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD)
citeinfo.othercit: Only certified WBD was included for use in HydroDEM production. These data are tiled by U.S. State, therefore only selected states with full certification were used. The publication date for each state's WBD varies. (See Source Time Period of Content)

srcinfo.srccontr: 12-digit subwatershed divides from the Watershed Boundary Dataset (WBD) were used (for states where certified WBD was available) as a ridgeline enforcment factor in a process called "walling" in the production of HydroDEMs. The HydroDEMs are the source data from which NHD Catchments are delineated from. Catchments with coincident boundaries with the WBD are in conformance with the WBD. NHDPlus Flow Direction and Accumulation Grids are hydrologic derivative products of the HydroDEMs.

citeinfo.origin: David W. Stewart, Alan Rea and David M. Wolock
citeinfo.title: USGS Streamgages Linked to the Medium Resolution NHD

srctime.srccurr: Date of data extract from NWIS

srcinfo.srccontr: Location of gages were spatially referenced to the NHDPlus flowlines to create a gaging station point event table, where for each gage in the database, the corresponding NHD Reachcode and measure are recorded. An early version of the dataset was also used for the QA/QC of NHDPlus cumulative drainage areas and estimates of mean annual stream flow.

procstep.procdesc: These NHD Plus stream hydrography layers for the Northwest U.S. have been edited and reconditioned to work consistently with the SSN package for implementing the spatial statistical stream models. Edits were performed using the STARS toolkit and consisted of removing unconnected stream segments and reducing braided stream segments to single-threaded streams.

cntorgp.cntorg: USDA Forest Service Boise Aquatic Sciences Lab

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: Common identifier of the NHD feature
Geographic Names Information System ID for the value in GNIS_Name
Feature Name from the Geographic Names Information System
Reach Code assigned to feature or reach on which an event is located
ComID of an NHD polygonal water feature through which an NHD "Artificial Path" flowline flows
Numeric codes for various feature attributes; definitions for codes found in the NHDFCode lookup table
Cumulative drainage area in square kilometers(sq km) at bottom of flowline
Hydrologic Unit Code 3 number - derived from Reach Code (not HUC3 boundaries)
attr.attrdefs: USFS RMRS Boise Aquatic Sciences Lab

attr.attrdef: Hydrologic Unit Code 4 number - derived from Reach Code (not HUC4 boundaries)
